Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; poorly modelled back, with roughly indicated elytra and prothorax by single lines, and, clypeus by two outline curves; at side, legs partially and crudely indicated; underside bearing a hieroglyphic inscription arranged vertically, with Maat feather to right; motif likely stamped; longitudinally pierced; thick greenish blue glaze; pale cream core.
Curator's comments: This scarab belongs to a type widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII B, subtype B37-41, see especially B37 for this piece). Though the hieroglyphic signs on its underside could have just some magical value, it seems more plausible that this was meant as cryptic writing for the name of Amun / Amun-Ra (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957) associated with the Horus name of Psamtek II, Menekhib. Variants of such an inscription appear on a few scarabs from the Scarab Factory (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 96-97, see especially 96 for this piece; on the various productions from the Scarab Factory, see Webb forthcoming). The Horus name of Psamtek II, sometimes written in an abbreviated way, is a very common inscription on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids (said to be men-ib-Ra in Gorton 1996, 93 and 111, but is actually Menekhib). For a similar inscription on an Egyptian blue scarab from Naukratis: BM 1886,0401.1665. Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 96)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 102-103, Type XXVIII B37)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.125) (phase 3)
Condition: Fair, though glaze quite eroded in some places
